Example

Find the polar coordinate form of

  1. \(z=3+4i\)
  2. \(z=-3-i\)

Solution

  1. Here \(r=|z|=\sqrt{3^2+4^2}=\sqrt{25}=5\qquad \theta=\text{arg}(z)=\tan^{-1}({4\over 3})=0.93 \mathrm{rad}\) so that\(z=5(\cos 0.93 \mathrm{rad}+i\sin 0.93 \mathrm{rad}).\)

  2. Here \(r=|z|=\sqrt{(-3)^2+(-1)^2}=\sqrt{10}\approx 3.16\qquad \theta=\text{arg}(z)=\tan^{-1}{(-1)\over {(-3)}}\) It is natural to assume that \(\tan^{-1}\dfrac{(-1)}{(-3)}=\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\).

    Using this value on your calculator (unless it is very sophisticated) you will obtain a value of about \(18.43^{\circ}\), which is approximately \(0.321\ \mathrm{radians}\), for \({\tan^{-1}({1\over 3})}\). This is incorrect since if we use the Argand diagram to plot \(z=-3-i\) we get: 



    The angle \(\theta\) is clearly \(-180^{\circ}+18.43^{\circ}=-161.57^{\circ}=-2.82 \mathrm{rad}\). This example warns us to take care when determining arg\((z)\) purely using algebra. You will always find it helpful to construct the Argand diagram to locate the particular quadrant into which your complex number is pointing. Your calculator cannot do this for you. Finally, in this example, \(z=3.16\ (\cos -2.82 \mathrm{rad}+i \sin -2.82 \mathrm{rad})\).
